title: SHO energy - box and 2 springs - compare v-max

content.question: A spring is attached to a fixed vertical wall and extends over a horizontal surface, as shown in the figure labeled “No Box.” In an experimental trial, a box is attached to and pushed against the spring, which has a spring constant <math alttext="k sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, compressing the spring an amount <math alttext="D sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>D</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> from its uncompressed length. The box is then released from rest and oscillates about its equilibrium position, with a maximum speed of <math alttext="v sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. In a second trial, a spring with spring constant <math alttext="2 k sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and the same uncompressed length is used. The same box is attached to and pushed against the new spring, compressing it an amount <math alttext="the fraction D sub 0 over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><msub><mi>D</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> from its uncompressed length. The box is released from rest and oscillates about its equilibrium position, with a maximum speed of <math alttext="v sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. There is negligible friction between the block and the surface. Are speeds <math alttext="v sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="v sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> equal? What reasoning can be used to support the claim?

choices.label: No. In the second trial, the elastic energy initially stored in the spring is less than in the first trial.
No. In the second trial, the acceleration of the box at a given displacement is greater in magnitude than in the first trial.
Yes. In the second trial, the maximum force exerted by the spring on the box is the same as in the first trial.
Yes. In the second trial, the spring exerts twice the amount of force over half the distance as in the first trial when moving the box from its maximum displacement to the equilibrium position.

content.answer: No. In the second trial, the elastic energy initially stored in the spring is less than in the first trial.
